Bimetallic metal-organic framework and graphene oxide nanohybrids induced carbonaceous reinforcement towards fire retardant epoxy: A novel alternative carbonization mechanism
Jing Zhang a, b, Zhi Li a, c, Lu Zhang a, b, Javier García Molleja a, De-Yi Wang a, *
a IMDEA Materials Institute, C/Eric Kandel, 2, 28906, Getafe, Madrid, Spain b Universidad Polit ecnica de Madrid, E.T.S. de Ingenieros de Caminos, 28040, Madrid, Spain c College of Materials Science and Engineering, Chongqing Jiaotong University, Chongqing, 400074, China

a b s t r a c t
The fire retarded intumescent epoxy resin (EP) composites were fabricated with the incorporation of bimetallic metal-organic framework (MOF) and graphene oxide (GO) nano-hybrids (MOF@GO) with intumescent fire retardants (IFR). EP/0.5MOF@GO-9.5IFR composite exhibited a 41% decrease in peak heat release rate, 30% decrease in total smoke production compared to reference sample EP/10IFR. According to in-situ morphology observation and X-ray tomography result, we observed such a novel carbonization phenomenon forming an alternately loose and accumulated structure. The further carbonaceous char analysis indicated the formation of a reinforced structure with fewer pores and excellent insulated property. Temperature test revealed that the synergistic effect between MOF@GO and IFR promoted the construction of the insulated carbonaceous char, which can maintain its temperature at around 400 C, thus providing sufficient time to build up the alternative reinforced char. Besides, the mechanical property of EP composite was also improved with a 11% increase in the tensile strength compared with that of EP/10IFR. In perspective, the observed carbonization phenomenon opens a window for understanding the mechanism for intumescent fire retardants.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Epoxy resin (EP) as one of the most popular thermosetting polymers is widely used as a high-performance material in coating, aerospace, automotives and composites [1]. Many studies have been reported to focus on the mechanical, thermal and multifunctional property of epoxy polymer composites [2e4]. However, the major drawback of high flammability restricted its applications. Nowadays, the replacement of toxic halogen-containing fire retardants (FRs) by frequently reported FRs, intumescent fire retardants (IFRs), was draw great attention due to their environment friendly and high efficiency [5]. Many papers have reported that the use of additives as synergists with IFRs is an effective way to improve fire retardancy with a lower loading and good mechanical property. For example, Caroline G erard et al. reported that using carbon nanotubes (CNT) and Octa Methyl Oligomeric
).
Silsesquioxanes (OMPOSS) respectively with APP in the epoxy to study the incorporation of nanoparticles on the reaction to fire of an epoxy resin [6]. The pHRR of EP with 4wt % APP and 1wt % of OMPOSS was decreased to 408 kW/m2 from 813 kW/m2. Jun-Sheng Wang et al. [7] explored the effect of metal compounds on the intumescent epoxy. The limiting oxygen index (LOI) values of the samples with 4.83wt% APP and 0.17wt% CoSA increase from 27.1 to 29.4, compared with epoxy resin containing 5wt% APP. Apart from the widely used synergists such as nano silica, metal compounds, a series of carbon materials such as CNT [6,8,9], graphene oxide [10], expanded graphite [11], nano diamonds [12], carbon nanofibers [13], carbon black [14] also exhibiting promising performance. Through the surface modification, carbon materials can provide further enhanced fire retardancy property for polymers [15e18]. In particular, graphene oxide (GO) as an important kind of carbon material have been applied in varies applications [19e21]. Further functionalizing GO with metallic compounds may be an effective method to construct fire retarded polymer combining the advantages of two materials. Moreover, a new class of nano porous material known as metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) which consists
1 J. Zhang, L. Zhi, X.-L. Qi, D.-Y. Wang, Size Tailored Bimetallic Metal-Organic Framework (MOF) on Graphene Oxide with Sandwich-like Structure as Functional
of metal ions and organic ligands has shown great potential in electromagnetic wave shielding [22], catalysis [23] and batteries [24]. The multi-component structure allows for the possibility of tuning the morphology, microstructures, making MOFs ideal materials to further modified with GO. However, the use of MOF derived materials as fire retardants usually leads to a low efficiency due to the formation of highly porous carbonaceous residues.
Regarding to the intumescent fire retardant behaviors of polymers, many studies have investigated the carbonization mechanisms. For instance, Bourbigot et al. investigated the variation of carbonaceous char structure in tradition polyolefin/APP/PER system under different stage of carbonization process [25,26]. Besides, a few studies have applied advanced X-ray tomography to study the morphology of intumescent carbonaceous char [27,28]. However, for each polymer composites, intumescent fire retardants may have different carbonization process and mechanism. Although, the intumescent behavior of fire retarded epoxy was widely studied, in this work, we observed a novel alternative carbonaceous structure with the use of X-ray tomography.
This work aims at studying the intumescent carbonization behavior and carbonaceous structure of fire retarded epoxy with the presence of MOF functionalized graphene oxide (MOF@GO) nano-hybrids as synergist. To the best of our knowledge, novel synergistic agent, MOF@GO, were for the first time used as synergist in intumescent EP composites. The fire retardancy and mechanical property of EP composites showed significant enhancements with dramatically reduced heat release rate, total smoke production and exhibited self-extinguishing behavior. The reinforced carbonaceous char with strong and compact structure is effective as a barrier protecting underlying polymers. The char was constructed at optimal temperature range around 400 C. Combined with further carbonaceous residue analysis by X-ray tomography and in-situ morphology observations, we observed a novel alternative carbonization phenomenon, which may help us better understand the intumescent carbonization process for polymer nanocomposites.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text: Ammonium polyphosphate (APP-205 BUDIT 3167) was provided by Chemische Fabrik Budenheim KG company. Zinc nitrate hexahydrate (Zn(NO3)2$6H2O, 98%), cobalt nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2$6H2O, 98%), 2-methylimisazole (2-MIM, 99%), and methanol (99.8%) were all provided by Sigma-Aldrich Chemical Co. Epoxy Resin (Epoxydhedraz C) was provided by R&G Faserverbundwerkstofffe GmbH-Germany. Diamino diphenyl sulfone (DDS) was supplied by TCI Chemicals Company.

sections.heading: 2.2. Preparation of MOF@GO nano-hybrids
sections.text:
GO was prepared by Hummers’method [29]. The preparation of MOF@GO was synthesized by the following procedure. In brief, Zn(NO3)2$6H2O (0.864 g) and Co(NO3)2$6H2O (0.576 g) were dissolved in 100ml methanol while 2-MIM (2.16 g) was dissolved in 100ml methanol, separately. 120mg GO solution was immersed into metal ion solution with vigorously stir and sonicated for 30min. Following this, the two solutions were mixed rapidly with vigorously stirring for 2 h. The precipitates were collected by centrifuge at 10000 rpm for 15min. The samples were dried in the vacuum oven at 80 C. Synthesis of Zn/CoMOFwas also prepared by same procedure without the addition of GO. The characterization
details of MOF@GO nano-hybrids can be found in our previous work,1 which also briefly summarized in the supporting information (S1.1).

sections.heading: 2.3. Preparation of EP composites
sections.text: A total weight fraction (10%) of IFR with MOF@GO, MOF and GO was used for preparing EP composites. The compositions of EP composites are presented in Table 1. The fillers were firstly incorporated into EPmatrix with a three-roll mill (EXAKT 80E, Germany) for 30min. Secondly, the curing agent DDS was added at 130 C with stirring. After the curing agent had completely dissolved, the mixture was transferred into a vacuum oven at 100 C for 7min and then poured into a preheated silicon mould. The curing procedures were set at 160 C for 1 h, 180 C for 2 h and 200 C for 1 h.

sections.heading: 2.4. Characterizations
sections.text:
Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was tested by TA Q50 with a heating rate at 10 C/min in nitrogen (N2) atmosphere. Isothermal degradation behavior was performed with TGA under N2 atmosphere. A rapid heating rate at 30 C/min to 400 C was applied to sample and followed by isothermal for 30min. The limiting oxygen index (LOI) test was performed with dimensions of 120 6.5 3mm2 based on standard ASTMD 2863-77. The vertical burning test was carried on UL 94 vertical flame chamber according to ASTM D3801. Cone calorimeter test (CCT) was carried out on facility (Fire Testing Technology) with sample dimension of 100.0mm 100.0mm 4.0mm according to the standard ISO 5660 at heat flux of 50 kW/m2. Raman spectra was carried on raman micro-spectroscopy system (Renishaw PLC). Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was carried out on SEM, EVO MA15, Zeiss. Temperature tests were detected with k-tpye thermocouples during the CCT test. X-ray nanotomography (Nanotom, Phoenix) was applied to explore the distribution of pores within residue. The cubic sample with dimension of 1 cm was prepared and it was obtained at the point which was equidistant to all sides of the sample and 1 cm below the surface of the char. Dynamic mechanical analysis (DMA) measurement was studied by dynamic mechanical analyzer (Q800, TA Instruments) with the single cantilever, 1 Hz frequency and ranging from room temperature to 250 C at a rate of 3 C/min. Tensile tests were carried out on a universal electromechanical testing machine (INSTRON 5966) under a maximum load of 10 kN according to the ISO standard (ISO 527-2). The tensile tests were carried out on dumb-bell samples with at least 5 specimens for each sample. The extension rate of 0.5mmmin 1 was chosen in the experiments.

sections.heading: 3.1. Thermal degradation behavior
sections.text: Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) is a useful indicator in the study of polymer flammability. The TGA and derivative thermogravimetry (DTG) curves of intumescent EP composites under N2 atmosphere with the MOF@GO as synergists were shown in Fig. 1 and the corresponding data are listed in Table 2. The residue remained after thermal degradation at 700 C can indicate the behavior in UL-94 test as the char on the surface can promote the inhibition of fire ignition. The amount of residue for the EP/ 0.5MOF@GO-9.5IFR sample was significant increased to 33.1%. Pure EP showed a one step process with an onset decomposition temperature (T5%) of 388 C. With the addition of only IFR, there is another slight step at the early stage due to the decomposition of APP under heat to yield polyphosphoric acid, thus to produce crosslinked structure and reinforced carbonaceous char [30,31]. With addition of MOF@GO into intumescent EP, it further accelerated the decomposition of intumescent EP, which is attributed to the catalytic oxidation effect of transmission metal-based MOF. Furthermore, the functionalized GO layer can significantly reduce the degradation rate, in which the maximum degradation rate decreased to 1.21. It indicated that MOF@GO may hinder the evolution of volatiles and suppress the release of smoke.

sections.heading: 3.2. Fire behavior
sections.text:
Fire retardancy of EP composites is first assessed by LOI and UL94 tests as shown in Fig. 2 (a) and Table 3. Pure EP is a flammable polymerwith an LOI value 23.8%, and it failed to pass the UL-94 test. With the addition of only IFR, the LOI value of EP/10IFR sample was increased to 25.4. Intumescent EP with the addition of MOF@GO exhibited an enhanced fire retardancy property with highest LOI value reach 26.8%. When the loading of MOF@GO was 0.5wt%, the EP/0.5MOF@GO-9.5IFR sample can reach UL-94 test V1 ratio with a total burning time only 16 s. It is worth noting that self extinction was observed after first ignition for the EP/0.5MOF@GO-9.5IFR sample. The jetting of pyrolytic gases was observed and the gases blew out the fire after the first ignition. This phenomenon was also reported with EP composites with the addition of DOPO-POSS [32,33]. As shown in Fig. 2 (a), the residues of selected samples showed that the EP/10IFR composite forms a fragile char, which is totally twisted. After modified with MOF@GO, adequate reinforced char was formed, which much stronger to withstand its original shape. This indicated that the improved fire retardancy property may result from the reinforced carbonaceous residue due to the synergistic effect of MOF@GO nano-hybrids with APP.
Cone calorimeter test (CCT), which can simulate bench scale fire and wealth information are applied to further evaluate the fire retardancy of EP composites. The parameters obtained from CCT including heat release rate (HRR), total smoke production (TSP) and carbon monoxide production (COP) are crucial in studying combustion performance and mechanism. Fig. 2 showed the HRR and TSP curves of pure EP and EP composites. With the addition of 10% IFR, the pHRR decreased slightly from 992 kW/m2 to 812 kW/m2. The pHRR of EP composites was dramatically reduced with the presence of MOF@GO as synergists. The lowest pHRR of EP/ 0.5MOF@GO-9.5IFR sample was 480 kW/m2 (41% decrease compared with EP/10IFR). By comparing with EP/0.5MOF-9.5IFR and EP/0.5GO-9.5IFR two samples (Fig. S2), it indicated that the synergistic effect in fire retardancy betweenMOF@GOwith IFR was mainly contributed to MOF due to the formation of much enhanced carbonaceous char (Fig. S4). Using the synergistic effect index (SE), which is defined as the ratio between the fire retardancy effect of the combination and the effect expected for the superposition of the effects of the single components, the quantitative synergy can be computed [34]. Using the pHRR for calculating the SE value for MOF and GO in the intumescent EP, the SE was 3.59, which is higher than 1. This indicates a superior effect through synergism between MOF and GO (S1.2). It is noted that different from the single peak curve of EP, EP composites with the presence of IFR exhibited two peaks. This is due to the formation protective char layer resulting from the decomposition of APP. However, the layer was broken down by the continuous heat and volatile gases and led to further fire growth. The appearance of the second peaks of intumescent EP were reduced and delayed significantly. Compared with the second heat release rate peak of EP/10IFR, the second peak of EP/ 0.5MOF@GO-9.5IFR sample drastically decreased by 59% and was delayed by 120 s, respectively. This result was consistent with the observed strong and compact residue after CCT as shown in Fig. S1. It revealed that the synergistic effect of MOF@GOwith APP showed an enhanced fire retardancy property by promoting the formation of a reinforced protecting char layer. Moreover, MOF@GO nanohybrids showed great performance in the smoke suppression with a 30% decrease in the TSP. Interestingly, EP/0.5MOF-9.5IFR sample did not exhibit strong smoke suppression effect alone with combination of IFR (Fig. S2). Apart from the excellent barrier effect of GO, and highly ordered porous structure of MOFs may also trapped the released smoke and formed increased tortuous path to delay the release of the smoke. However, MOF itself under combustion trends to promote the degradation of polymers due to the catalytic effect metal species. This leads to the smouldering of materials, thus the increased the TSP. Combined with GO, the formation of a reinforced and compact char residue can eliminate the smouldering. Thus, the trapped effect of MOF and barrier effect of

sections.heading: 3.3. In-situ morphology and analysis of char under combustion
sections.text:
In order to explore the dynamic carbonization process of intumescent epoxy, the in-situ morphology observation from CCT was stopped at the moment pure EP reached pHRR (130 s) and at the end of the experiments (500 s) as shown in Fig. S5.
Pure EP is a non-charring polymer with limited char formation, which was not sufficient to protect the polymer during the whole combustion process. Enormous pores from the residue char layer were observed by SEM (Fig. S6). With the addition of 10% APP, a significantly greater amount of intumescent char is formed. However, the quality of its char was limited. As shown in Fig. 3(a and b), at pHRR, enormous bubbles are observed with some of them already being broken and its cross-section areas also have numerous visible big holes. This related to the decomposition of APP and other volatiles, which break the char layer due to its weak structure. At the end of the test, evenmore pores can be observed in the residue. These images revealed that EP/10IFR sample promoted the formation of intumescent char to protect the underlying polymer. However,the quality residue is not sufficient.
The exterior and interior morphologies of EP/0.5MOF@GO9.5IFR residue at pHRR and at the end are shown in Fig. 3(eej). During swelling, the sample bent first, and at the same time a compact layer was formed at the bottom of the residue, which acts
as a barrier and leads to the formation of a chamber as shown in Fig. 3 (f). Above the chamber, the residue layer acted as a dome further protecting the underlying polymer. The cross-section view of residue stopped at pHRR revealed that the visible pores were much smaller than that of the EP/10IFR sample. Corresponding SEM images confirmed that awell-structured residuewas observedwith fewer pores on it. At the end of the test, the interior image of the sample showed fewer bubbles and pores, which was consistent with the fire test results. This in-situ morphology observation indicated that the carbonaceous layer exhibited an obvious difference during the early stage of fire stage with reinforced structure due to the synergistic effect of MOF@GO with IFR.
X-ray tomography which can represent the X-ray absorption of materials, was applied to the EP/0.5MOF@GO-9.5IFR sample to explore the inner structure of its residue after CCT based on the simulated 3Dmodel. As shown in Fig. 4 (a), the overall sample from the front view showed clearly the porous structure of the residue. The corresponding model exhibited a compact structure (Fig. 4 (b)). Interestingly, there are two accumulated layers at the center and near the bottom, while the other parts of the sample are more homogeneously. The sample exhibited an alternately loose and accumulated inner structure. The simulated 3D model with half structure also proved the existence of loose layers and accumulated layers (Fig. 4 (c)). Moreover, the simulated slices from the

Further char analysis by Raman spectrum was applied to study the quality of the residue, where there were two main peaks at 1350 and 1600 cm 1 corresponding to the D band and G band, respectively (Fig. 5). The value of ID/IG (listed in Table S2), for EP/

Therefore, we can conclude that MOF@GO with transition metals species can promote the formation of a better microstructure that may reinforce the carbonaceous residue with enhanced quality.

sections.heading: 3.4. Temperature analysis of intumescent EP composites
sections.text:
In order to further explain the different performances of EP composites in fire retardancy and the relationship between temperature and carbonization process, the thermocouples were placed at different positions of a sample (top, middle and bottom) to detect the temperature range during CCT and thus the thermo physical evolution of EP composites. The temperature profile of EP, EP/10IFR and EP/0.5MOF@GO-9.5IFR were shown in Fig. 6(a and b, c). The differences between the middle and bottom temperatures for all three samples were plotted in Fig. 6(d and e). With the incorporation of IFR, the bottom and middle temperatures of EP/ 10IFR significantly decreased by 57 C and 128 C compared with that of pure EP. However, the bottom and middle temperatures finally converge towards similar temperatures. This indicated that the intumescent char can prevent the heat transfer but its loose structure with big pores leading to the barrier of the char is not sufficient. In particular, the temperature gradient of EP/ 0.5MOF@GO-9.5IFR is much more significant. The bottom temperature further reduced by 121 C compared with the EP/10IFR sample, which indicating a thermal insulation intumescent char due to the excellent thermal property of GO [37].
It is worth noting that a platform was observed on both of the middle and bottom temperature profile for each sample. This platform is much wider after combining APP with MOF@GO. More interesting, these platforms were appeared in accordance with the significant mass enhanced period in the mass lost curve during the CCT. As shown in Fig. 6 (f), between 100 and 300 s, the loss of weight for EP/0.5MOF@GO-9.5IFR samples was much slower. At a similar time range, both the middle and bottom layers of the residue showed a platformwithout a significant temperature increase at around 370 and 410 C, respectively. The combined mass loss curves with HRR curves (Fig. 6 (f)) showed that the significant mass enhanced period is exactly the period where heat release rate increases slowly. It revealed that at the temperature around 400 C,
MOF@GO and APP exhibited significant synergistic effect and built up an insulated carbonaceous char. This provides sufficient time for constructing the alternative reinforced char. Depended on how long this insulated char can maintain, the fire retardancy property varied. The reconstructed residue was gradually broken under the constant heat, which leads to an increased release of heat again.
As show in Fig. 7, a rapid rump process (30 C/min) was applied in TGA to simulate a forced combustion process and isothermal at 400 C according to the temperature test. The calculated weight loss curves for EP composites were obtained by the linear combination of EP/10IFR and MOF@GO. The difference between experimental and calculated weight (Fig. 7 (b), area (I)) demonstrated remarkable promotion of the charring process which started at around 10min (340 C). The maximum weight difference showed at 11.6min with a value of 6 % at 400 C. However, after this moment, the weight difference significantly decreased which corresponded to the deterioration in the charring process (area (II)) [38]. The optimal temperature for the construction of carbonaceous char is the same as the temperature test result at around 400 C.
Therefore, we can conclude that the catalytic carbonization effect of MOF@GO nano-hybrids promoted the formation of reinforced char residue with good insulation property. With the maintenance of temperature of char at around 400 C, the char can construct a compact structure to resistant the damage from evolution of volatiles.
Based on the analysis above, the proposed fire retardancy and smoke suppression mechanism is illustrated in Fig. 8. The fire performance of EP composites highly depends on the quality and insulation property of intumescent carbonaceous char, which can behave like a strong barrier to isolate the heat and suppress smoke. The synergistic effect of transition metal based MOF@GO with IFR promotes the construction of the reinforced carbonaceous layer between 350 and 400 C. During this time, firstly EP composites swell and form a chamber with a compact barrier layer at the bottom of sample and a dome on the top.Meanwhile, the insulation char is equipped the ability to maintain the temperature at around 400 C to provide sample sufficient time to construct the compact char residue with fewer pores. Therefore, an alternately loose and accumulated inner structure of residue was observed. These strong char layers are effective to prevent the heat transfer and volatile gases during the forced combustion test.

sections.heading: 3.5. Mechanical property
sections.text:
Besides the excellent fire retardancy property, the mechanical property of intumescent EP composites is also play an important role, which was measured by dynamic mechanical analysis (DMA) and tensile test. The storage modulus (G’) and tan delta (d) of EP composites were shown in Fig. 9. The result indicated that the storage modulus of EP/0.5MOF@GO-9.5IFR sample increased to 2257MPa. This is mainly ascribed to the better interfacial interaction between the fillers with EP matrix, which hinder the mobility of the polymer chain [39]. A better dispersion state also promotes
an enhanced storage modulus [40]. GO can behave as the platform to support the growth of MOF preventing the accumulation of MOF. On the other hand, the growth of MOF enlarges the GO layers and strips the layers leading to an improved dispersion state [41]. With the increase in temperature, the storage modulus decreased gradually due to energy dissipation during the transition from glass state to a rubber state. Meanwhile, the glass transition temperature (Tg) of EP composites as shown in Fig. 8 (b) did not show significant difference between 202 and 204 C, which enables epoxy to have a far wider range of applications.
The stress-strain curves of pure EP and EP composites exhibited a typical brittle fracture characteristic (Fig.10). Comparedwith pure EP/10IFR (52.2MPa), the tensile strength for EP/0.5MOF@GO-9.5IFR increased to 57.9MPa, which exhibited an increase around 11%. This also indicated that those fillers had strong interaction with EP matrix due to their high specific surface area and inorganic-organic hybrid character of MOF, which can help to absorb energy within plastically deformed zone [42].

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text: In summary, MOF@GO nano-hybrids are efficient synergists with the use of IFR for simultaneously improving the fire retardancy and mechanical properties of EP. The optimal sample EP/ 0.5MOF@GO-9.5IFR exhibited a 41% decrease in pHRR compared with EP/10IFR and self-extinction behavior in the UL-94 test. Those enhancements in fire retardancy and smoke suppression were attributed to the barrier effect of highly reinforced carbonaceous char. The analysis for carbonaceous char indicated that the synergistic effect between MOF@GO and IFR at the temperature around 400 C promoted the formation of a strong and insulated intumescent char with fewer pores. A novel alternative dynamic carbonization phenomenon was observed with formation of loose and accumulated layer. This is attributed to under the process the released volatiles enlarge the reinforced char layer, part of volatile accumulated, thus pushing part of the layers accumulate. Furthermore, the intumescent EP composites also exhibited enhanced mechanical performances with a 11% increase in tensile strength due to improved interaction between the fillers and matrix. The novel alternative intumescent carbonization process may provide in-depth understanding the mechanism of intumescent fire retardant polymer.

metadata.abstractText: The fire retarded intumescent epoxy resin (EP) composites were fabricated with the incorporation of bimetallic metal-organic framework (MOF) and graphene oxide (GO) nano-hybrids (MOF@GO) with intumescent fire retardants (IFR). EP/0.5MOF@GO-9.5IFR composite exhibited a 41% decrease in peak heat release rate, 30% decrease in total smoke production compared to reference sample EP/10IFR. According to in-situ morphology observation and X-ray tomography result, we observed such a novel carbonization phenomenon forming an alternately loose and accumulated structure. The further carbonaceous char analysis indicated the formation of a reinforced structure with fewer pores and excellent insulated property. Temperature test revealed that the synergistic effect between MOF@GO and IFR promoted the construction of the insulated carbonaceous char, which can maintain its temperature at around 400 C, thus providing sufficient time to build up the alternative reinforced char. Besides, the mechanical property of EP composite was also improved with a 11% increase in the tensile strength compared with that of EP/10IFR. In perspective, the observed carbonization phenomenon opens a window for understanding the mechanism for intumescent fire retardants. © 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
